Residential load data is limited due to the high cost of collection and privacy concerns. This paper proposes a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-based method to model complex residential load patterns and generate synthetic yet realistic load data. A generation-focused weight selection method is used to address the mode collapse problem and generate diverse load patterns. The method is evaluated using real-world data and outperforms three state-of-the-art benchmark models in preserving sequence-level temporal dependencies and aggregated-level distributions of load patterns.

Residential energy use accounts for approximately 20% of greenhouse gas emissions in the United States. Responsible energy consumption promotes energy saving, energy efficiency upgrades, and the use of renewable energy, reducing carbon footprint and CO2 emissions to combat climate change. Load profiling, load forecasting, and demand response can be performed by analyzing residential load data to inform responsible energy consumption. However, the lack of access to diverse and high-quality residential load data hinders responsible energy consumption due to the cost-intensive data collection process and privacy concerns.

Studies have been conducted to model and generate residential load to overcome the challenges of limited access to residential load data. One approach models individual appliances' electricity consumption and aggregates it to generate load data at a household level. However, this approach requires intrusive sensors, which is costly and time-consuming, making it difficult to scale up. Another approach models residential load directly at the household level using methods such as Gaussian Mixture Model or Markov Chain Model. Recently, Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) have been used to generate synthetic energy data.

A conditional GAN-based generative model using the Auxiliary Classifier GAN has been proposed for residential load data generation, which is promising for its low cost and high scalability. However, residential load data can be diverse due to various housing properties and lifestyles of energy users. Most results generated using top-down approaches suffer from low diversity problems. To overcome these challenges, a novel Residential Load Pattern Generation method (RLPGen) is developed. The method can capture time dependencies within daily load patterns and generate diverse load data reflecting different lifestyles.

The performance of RLPGen is evaluated against three representative benchmarks using real-world data. RLPGen outperforms the benchmarks by achieving higher similarity to real data and better diversity within generated load patterns.

The RLPGen method is trained and evaluated using real-world data from the Pecan Street database, which contains smart meter data of hourly load recordings. After data cleaning, 417 households' hourly load data from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2017, is obtained. The method focuses on load patterns using normalized hourly smart meter data and develops a novel method to generate diverse daily load patterns reflecting real-world consumption behaviors.

A future work can be conducted to compare RLPGen with non-GAN and non-ML based methods, and further extension can be done on the approach to perform residential load demand data generation.

To address the limitations of existing top-down and bottom-up methods, an LSTM-based GAN model is developed along with a weight selection method to learn and generate residential load patterns. The model introduces autoencoders for adversarial training at the hidden space level and performs weakly-supervised training for finer control over temporal dynamics. LSTM units are used across the model to improve the ability to learn time-series load data. The detailed model design and implementation are presented.
